Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2009 06:36PM glendag wrote: Lories - I enrolled in the TailorX trial thinking my score would be so low I wouldn't qualify for the study.  Score came back 20.  I was randomized to do the chemo.  I was glad to not have to agonize over the decision to do chem or not.  I felt comfortable having the decision made for me.  Now I'm glad that I did it - I have the peace of mind to know that I've done everything possible.  The experience certainly wasn't fun.  But it wasn't horrible either.  4-TC.  As others have said - very doable.
Posts.Title: TailorX Trial InfoSeeker2008 Lories

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2009 06:40PM glendag wrote: I also came back with a score of 20.  Was randomized to do chemo.  4tx TC -- I'm really glad now that I did it.  I know I've done everything possible.
Posts.Title: TailorX Trial InfoSeeker2008 Lories

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 08:57AM glendag wrote: I did 4 courses AC.  every 3 weeks.  Got anti nausea meds with the infusion and was sent home with a schedule for taking anti nausea drugs.  I drank 64 oz minimum water day before, day of and day after.   No nausea but spaceiness probably due to the drugs.  I had infusion on Wednesday, worked Thursdays and Fridays.  Rested on the weekend (it was hard to "focus" - again probably because of the drugs) I took Mondays off and then back to work until next treatment.  I did take ativan at night which helped with sleeping. I was surprised at how not horrible it was.  I think it is really important to take the drugs on schedule whether you are nauseous or not.  Best wishes,  g
Posts.Title: AC Triciaski Triciaski

Posts.Content: glendag wrote: Does anyone have experience with Anadyne therapy or Metanx r/x for treating peripheral neuropathy due to chemo? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Neuropathy Treatments glendag VickyC10

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2010 11:47PM glendag wrote: I agree with Geri "there is no diagnostic test that I would ever feel comfortable with."  I went with the prophylactic mastectomy for three main reasons: I had lobular cancer, it was multifocal, not seen on mammogram or ultrasound.  Fortunately I was node negative and feel that I dodged a huge bullet.  I wanted all the breast tissue gone, especially with the lobular cancer.  I didn't want to wait for it to possibly show up later, be missed by survaillence and get past the lymph nodes.  It is a huge sense of relief for me.  I hope you find peace with your decision, it isn't an easy one to make. glenda

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2009 12:49PM glendag wrote: I only had a snb and single mast but experienced similar problems.  started p/t about 3 months out and it was invaluable.  She gave me additional stretching and strength building exercises.  It was helpful to have someone show me exactly how far to push.  I was afraid of pushing too hard and creating lymphedema problems. I now have pretty much full range of motion.  my p/t is a certified lymphedema specialist and also did scar massage which helped too.
